title: Prefigurative Community Building (Part 3): Weaving Power With the Land
summary: How to start a community garden or guerrilla gardening project without reproducing Power Over dynamics. A practical guide to growing food together as an act of collective resistance and renewal.

Food.summary: Start community gardens that practice Power With instead of hierarchical organizing.

level0: Form a core pod of 2-6 people who share interest and trust
Host conversation about what kind of garden you want to build together
level1: Find unused space or negotiate access to land
Host regular open hours for planting and tending together
level2: Create inclusive design with living maps and multi-language access
Host seed swaps and material sourcing collectively
level3: Establish permanent community garden with horizontal governance
Create network of connected gardens across neighborhoods

Community.summary: Build relationships through shared land stewardship and collective care.

level0: Establish shared values like transparency, consent, and ecological respect
level1: Use consensus or sociocratic methods for group decisions
Create conflict culture based on listening and repair
level2: Host celebrations, solstice meals, and harvest parties
Invite neighbors to take cuttings and seeds
level3: Build comprehensive community resilience through garden networks

Knowledge.summary: Learn ecological practices while sharing skills horizontally.

level0: Learn about local ecology by observing site before planting
Ask elders and neighbors about traditional crops
level2: Develop expertise in native species and pollinator plants
Teach others horizontal organizing through gardening
level3: Become regional resource for ecological land practices
Train others in Power With gardening methods

Narrative.summary: Transform relationship to land, each other, and systems of power.

level0: Practice seeing land as relationship rather than property
level1: Document garden projects through collective storytelling
Share stories of land reclamation and resistance
level2: Help others understand Power With vs Power Over through gardening
level3: Shift cultural narrative around land access and food sovereignty
